name.text: Introduction to sets and set notation

questiontext.text:
a) Which one of the following statements defines a set and explain why set theory is important in mathematics? [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

b) Consider a set \(A\) of even numbers less than \({@selected_number@}\):

Select statements which hold for elements in set \(A\).

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

A set is a well-defined collection of objects that share certain properties or characteristics.

In set theory, sets serve as the fundamental building blocks, and they are used to organize and classify various mathematical objects.

Set theory is vital in mathematics because it provides a rigorous foundation for other mathematical concepts and operations.

It helps define relationships between different elements, aids in understanding mathematical structures and enables the development of formal mathematical proofs.

Example of a well-defined set:

Let's consider the set \(A\) of even numbers less than \({@selected_number@}\):

\(A = {@even_numbers@}\)

In this example, \(A\) is a well-defined set because it clearly states the property that all its elements are even numbers less than \({@selected_number@}\).

Illustration using notation:

To represent the elements of set \(A\) using notation:

\({@ta_2_a@} ({@element_to_check@}\) is an element of \(A)\)

\({@ta_2_b@} ({@element_to_check@}\) is not an element of \(A)\)
